Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story: I was at my desk, halfway through my assigned report, when my phone buzzed. It was a new client, calling during my scheduled check-in. “Hey, could you walk me through the basic settings on the machine?” she asked, her tone friendly but expectant. As a machine repairer, I knew I should take the time to guide her—after all, helping clients understand their equipment was part of my job, and I wanted her to feel supported. But as a colleague, I also had my own tasks to finish. The report wasn’t urgent, but I’d promised my team I’d have it done by the end of the day, and I didn’t want to let them down. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure build. If I spent time with the client now, I’d fall behind on my work. But if I brushed her off, I’d be neglecting my responsibility to provide good service. My mind raced, torn between being a reliable teammate and a helpful repairer, unsure which expectation to meet first.
